DataElement.preferredName: Non-Steroidal Aromatase Inhibitor Resistance Process Patient Description
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Description of the setting in which the patient developed resistance to prior non-steroidal aromatase inhibitor (AI) treatment.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Non-Steroidal Aromatase Inhibitor Resistance Process Patient Description
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Description of the setting in which the patient developed resistance to a non-steroidal aromatase inhibitor treatment.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Non-Steroidal Aromatase Inhibitor Resistance Process Patient
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An aromatase inhibitor with a non-steroidal structure. Non-steroidal aromatase inhibitors work by reversible competition with the enzyme.:A Resistance Process consists of activities of biologic molecules or complexes involved in processes that maintain immunity to, or counteract, defeat, or withstand the effects of, an antagonistic agent.:A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Concepts.definition: An aromatase inhibitor with a non-steroidal structure. Non-steroidal aromatase inhibitors work by reversible competition with the enzyme.

A Resistance Process consists of activities of biologic molecules or complexes involved in processes that maintain immunity to, or counteract, defeat, or withstand the effects of, an antagonistic agent.
A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An agent that enhances the activity or therapeutic effect of another pharmacologic substance without having much, if any, therapeutic impact by itself.

Concepts.definition: An agent that enhances the activity or therapeutic effect of another pharmacologic substance without having much, if any, therapeutic impact by itself.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment designed to be used as a first step toward shrinking the cancer and in evaluating response to drugs and other agents. Induction therapy is followed by additional therapy to eliminate whatever cancer remains.

Concepts.definition: Therapy administered prior to the primary treatment for the purpose of making the primary treatment more effective.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Far along in course.: Unable to be removed with surgery.: A disease that is confined to a specific organ or tissue and has not spread to other anatomic sites.

Concepts.definition: Not capable of being removed by surgery.
A disease that is confined to a specific organ or tissue and has not spread to other anatomic sites.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Concepts.definition: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer that has spread from where it started to nearby tissue or lymph nodes.: Having to do with metastasis, which is the spread of cancer from the primary site (place where it started) to other places in the body.: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread from its original site of growth to nearby tissues or lymph nodes.
A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.
